newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Cedenco sees profit in yr to Sept 1997.
newsitem.headline: Cedenco sees profit in yr to Sept 1997.

text.p: Cedenco Foods Ltd on Thursday said it had virtually completed its major restructuring and was forecasting a return to profitability in the year to September, 1997.

Managing director Dean Witters said the establishment of Cedenco Australia and the restructuring of Cedenco's remaining operations had resulted in significant one-off costs and a substantial revision to its balance sheet for the financial year to September 30, 1996.

Cedenco expects a full year loss of NZ$6.1 million for that year, including an operating loss for the final six months of $1.8 million (before tax) and the effect of the one-off restructuring costs and associated write downs.
As a result fixed asset values and debt levels are both expected to fall significantly.

As Cedenco began its new financial year, however, restructuring left it better placed to capitalise on its technical expertise in the growing, processing and industrial marketing of specialist food products.
Witters said the establishment of Cedenco Australia gave the company a secure base in its principal market, Australia, alongside its major customers.
Cedenco Australia, a joint venture with Cerebos Australia, will be Australasia's largest tomato processing operation.
Cedenco's state-of-the-art tomato paste and dice processing plant, being erected on site in Victoria after shipping to Australia, will be ready to process its first tomato crop in early 1997.
Cedenco Australia will supply 40 percent of the Australian tomato paste market and has already entered into contracts with customers covering the majority of its expected production.
In New Zealand, Cedenco plans to expand and diversify its Gisborne operations, including the production of vegetable powders, fresh vegetables and its nursery operations.
